intro: Orthocarpus columbinus, commonly known as the Columbia orthocarpus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed capsule that splits open to release seeds. Orthocarpus columbinus is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
